climtools module¶

climtools.KinKmeans(var, nk=False, tol=0.0001, n_init=100)[source]¶

Uses pseudo-F to estimate the best number of K in K-Means From MJCarvalho GapStatistics

Parameters:
  • var (numpy) – Numpy array with input data
  • nk (int) – Initial number of K
  • tol (float) – Tolerance for K-Means
  • n_init (int) – Number of initializations for K-Means
Return int:

Number of K and f statistic
climtools.cclimatology(var, time, relative=False, smooth=False, window=15, israin=False)[source]¶

Calculates the daily climatology (time = 365/6 days) and the anomaly in relation to that climatology

Parameters:
  • var (numpy) – Numpy array with data (usualy time, lat, lon)
  • time (list) – List containing the datetime for var
  • bool (relative) – True retuns relative anomaly
  • smooth (bool) – True smooths climatology with runing mean
  • window (int) – Window for running mean
  • israin (bool) – True for rain data (uses sum instead of mean)
Return numpy:

Array with daily climatology
Return numpy:

Array of the anomaly
Example:

clim, anl = cclimatology(var, timei, **kwargs)
climtools.eof(var, neof=30, dim='field')[source]¶

Calculates the Empirical Orthogonal Functions for a (time, lat, lon) array

Parameters:
  • var (numpy) – Numpy array containing the input data to compute eof
  • neof (int) – number of eof to retain
  • dim (str) – If set to ‘field’ returns a lat, lon shape array
Return numpy:

eof field
Return numpy:

principal components
Return numpy:

principal component variance
climtools.runmean(x, N)[source]¶

Performes a runing mean filter over a set of data

Parameters:
  • x (numpy) – array of data
  • N (int) – running window
Return numpy:

filtered data
climtools.svd(var1, var2, neof)[source]¶

Calculates the Singular Value Decompisition between two datasets

Parameters:
  • var1 (numpy) – data field with (time, lat, lon) shape
  • var2 (numpy) – data field with (time, lat, lon) shape
  • neof (int) – number of eof to retain
Returns numpy:

svd parameters (6 outputs)
